titleStmt.title: To his honoured Friend George Buck on this his Revivall of the Royall-Name of the PLANTAGENETS.
titleStmt.author: Codrington, Robert

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: To his honoured Friend George Buck on this his Revivall of the Royall-Name of the PLANTAGENETS.
analytic.author: Codrington, Robert

monogr.title: The great Plantagenet. Or a continued succession of that royall name, from Henry the Second, to our sacred soveraigne King Charles. By Geo. Buck, Gent
monogr.author: Buck, George

div.head: To his honoured Friend George Buck on this his Revivall of the Royall-Name of the PLANTAGENETS.

l.hi: KIngs are above their Fates, and glorious live,
Though layd in Dust, by the prerogative

lg.l: They have o're Fame: but this Religious debt
Due to the Name of Great Plantagenet,

l.hi: So long uncancel'd lay, we did distrust
Their Names would be more buried then their Dust:

lg.l: Till some rich Mercy thy learn'd Quill did wooe,

l.hi: To pay this Debt which none but it could doe.
And now so cleere discharg'd, againe their Name

lg.l: Is borne in Triumph on the wings of Fame,

l.hi: And to the deeds to which their life did climbe,

lg.l: They now in Dust have learn'd to conquer Time:

l.hi: For this their Royall gratitude returnes

lg.l: To thee the Laurells which now crowne their Vrnes.

l.hi: Who would not wish this Wreath his owne, which springs
Ioyntly bequeath'd thee from so many Kings?
